subject: test1
mainTitle: Types of Transportation Cards in Australia

details.title: Opal Card (New South Wales)
details.subTitle: Used in Sydney, the Blue Mountains, and surrounding areas.

details.title: Myki Card (Victoria)
details.subTitle: Used in Melbourne and nearby regions.

details.title: Go Card (Queensland)
details.subTitle: Used in Brisbane and the Gold Coast.

details.title: How to Use Transportation Cards
details.subTitle: Purchase: Easily available at train stations, convenience stores, or online.
Top-up: Recharge using machines or mobile apps.
Usage: Simply tap your transportation card on the terminal (Tap on/Tap off), and the fare will be automatically calculated.

details.title: Queuing Etiquette
details.subTitle: Lining up is a basic rule of etiquette in Australia.

details.title: No Tipping Culture
details.subTitle: Tipping is not expected in Australia.

details.title: Speaking Quietly in Public
details.subTitle: Speaking too loudly in public places like buses, trains, and cafes can be seen as impolite.

details.title: Sharing Food Culture
details.subTitle: In Australia, even among close friends, taking food from someone else's plate without permission is considered impolite.

details.title: Regional Employment Requirement
details.subTitle: The 494 visa requires the applicant to work in a designated regional area of Australia, which excludes major cities.

details.title: Autumn (March–May)
details.subTitle: Brings cooler weather and beautiful autumn foliage, especially in places like Melbourne and Tasmania.

details.title: Employer Sponsorship
details.subTitle: Applicants must have a job offer from an Australian employer who is willing to sponsor them.

details.title: Skilled Occupation
details.subTitle: The applicant must work in an occupation listed on Australia's approved skills list.

details.title: Temporary Visa with Pathway to Permanent Residency
details.subTitle: The 494 visa is a temporary visa valid for 5 years.

mainTitle: Types of Transportation Cards in Australia

details.title: Summer (December–February)
details.subTitle: Summer is characterized by high temperatures and strong sunlight, making it an ideal season for beach activities like swimming and surfing.

details.title: Autumn (March–May)
details.subTitle: Brings cooler weather and beautiful autumn foliage, especially in places like Melbourne and Tasmania.

details.title: Go Card (Queensland)
details.subTitle: Used in Brisbane and the Gold Coast.

details.title: Winter (June–August)
details.subTitle: While the southern regions experience cold temperatures, the north, including Queensland and Darwin, remains relatively warm.
The ski season starts in the mountainous areas of New South Wales and Victoria.

details.title: Spring (September–November)
details.subTitle: Spring sees rising temperatures and blooming flowers, with Canberra’s Floriade Festival being a major attraction.
Outdoor activities such as hiking, camping, and picnicking become more popular.

details.title: Independent Visa
details.subTitle: The 189 visa is an independent visa that can be applied for without employer or family sponsorship

details.title: Skilled Occupation
details.subTitle: Applicants must work in an occupation listed on Australia's approved skills list.

details.title: Permanent Residency Visa
details.subTitle: The 189 visa grants permanent residency, allowing holders to live, work, and study in Australia indefinitely.

details.title: Points-Based System
details.subTitle: Applicants must meet the required points threshold.

details.title: Meat Pie
details.subTitle: It is one of the most popular snacks in Australia, featuring a crispy pastry filled with minced meat and gravy.

details.title: Vegemite Toast
details.subTitle: Vegemite Toast is a staple breakfast item in Australia.

details.title: BBQ Culture
details.subTitle: BBQ Culture is an essential part of Australian life, with various meats and seafood

details.title: Chicken Parmigian
details.subTitle: It is typically served with fries and a side salad and is especially popular in Victoria.

details.title: State or Territory Nomination
details.subTitle: The 190 visa requires nomination by a state.

details.title: Permanent Residency Visa
details.subTitle: This visa grants permanent residency, allowing holders to live, work.

details.title: Skilled Occupation
details.subTitle: Applicants must work in an occupation listed on Australia’s skilled occupation list.

details.title: Points-Based System
details.subTitle: The 190 visa operates on a points-based system.

details.title: Coles
details.subTitle: Coles is known for its stable product quality and regular discount events. Customers can earn Flybuys points, which are redeemable for future savings. While prices are on the higher end, the store's consistent promotions make it a good option for regular shoppers.

details.title: Woolworths
details.subTitle: Woolworths offers high-quality fresh produce and has a loyalty program called Everyday Rewards, which gives you discounts on future purchases. While some products can be more expensive than Coles, Woolworths makes up for it with premium items and great weekly specials.

details.title: Aldi
details.subTitle: Aldi focuses on budget-friendly options, offering mainly private-label products. The store is known for its competitive prices, and the checkout process is quick.

details.title: Employer Sponsorship
details.subTitle: The 482 visa requires sponsorship from an Australian employer.

details.title: Temporary Visa
details.subTitle: his visa is temporary, typically valid for 2 to 4 years.

details.title: Skilled Occupation
details.subTitle: The applicant must work in an occupation listed on Australia’s skilled occupation list.

details.title: Pathway to Permanent Residency
details.subTitle: After holding the 482 visa for a period.

details.title: Medicare & Walk-in Clinics
details.subTitle: Medicare is available for eligible residents, providing free or low-cost medical services, including visits to doctors and hospitals.

details.title: Buying Medicine at Pharmacies
details.subTitle: Common over-the-counter medications like Panadol (pain relief) and Telfast (allergy relief) can be bought without a prescription at pharmacies.

details.title: Handling Emergencies
details.subTitle: For life-threatening emergencies, dial 000 for an ambulance.

details.title: Accessing Healthcare Services
details.subTitle: Australia offers Medicare and walk-in clinics for affordable medical care.

details.title: Independent Visa
details.subTitle: The 189 visa is an independent visa that can be applied for without employer or family sponsorship.

details.title: Skilled Occupation
details.subTitle: Applicants must work in an occupation listed on Australia's approved skills list.

details.title: Permanent Residency Visa
details.subTitle: The 189 visa grants permanent residency, allowing holders to live, work, and study in Australia indefinitely.

details.title: Points-Based System
details.subTitle: Applicants must meet the required points threshold, and higher-scoring candidates are given priority.

details.title: TFN & ABN Registration
details.subTitle: To legally work in Australia, you need a Tax File Number (TFN).

details.title: Job Search & Resume Tips
details.subTitle: Job-seeking websites like SEEK, Indeed, and Gumtree are great tools for finding work in Australia.

details.title: Workplace Etiquette & Minimum Wage
details.subTitle: The national minimum wage is approximately $23 per hour.

details.title: Rights & Fair Work
details.subTitle: Australia has strong labor laws to protect workers. The Fair Work Ombudsman ensures employees receive fair wages, proper working conditions, and protection against unfair dismissal.

details.title: Regional Visa
details.subTitle: The 491 visa is a regional visa.

details.title: State or Family Sponsorship
details.subTitle: This visa can be sponsored by a state or territory government or a family member

details.title: Temporary Visa
details.subTitle: The 491 visa is temporary and valid for 5 years.

details.title: Skilled Occupation
details.subTitle: Applicants must work in an occupation listed on Australia’s skilled occupation list.

details.title: Temporary Purpose Visa
details.subTitle: The 408 visa is granted to individuals participating in activities

details.title: Sponsorship Required
details.subTitle: To apply for this visa, a sponsor, such as an employer or organization.

details.title: Temporary Stay
details.subTitle: This visa is temporary, typically valid for the duration of the activity.

details.title: Permission for Specific Activities
details.subTitle: The visa grants permission for the holder to engage in defined activities within Australia.
